The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
Does the concept of a/an Symmetric Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Dihedral Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The definition of a Dihedral Group involves the concept of permutations, specifically mentioning permutations 
	sigma = (1, ..., n) and 
	tau = 
		1 2 3 ... n 
		1 n n-1 ... 2
These permutations are elements of the Symmetric Group, as they represent bijective self-maps of the set {1, ..., n}. The Symmetric Group is essentially the group of all such permutations. Therefore, understanding what permutations are and how they operate within the context of a group (like the Symmetric Group) is crucial for defining the Dihedral Group, which is generated by specific permutations of the Symmetric Group. Thus, the concept of the Symmetric Group is necessary to fully understand and define the Dihedral Group.
